author: Deena Coster
title: Police urge public to be more security conscious after spike in burglaries
text:
Police urge public to be more security conscious after spike in burglaries DEENA COSTER Last updated 19:07, February 28 2017 123RF 
Leaving windows or doors unlocked is making it too easy for burglars, police say. 
Police data shows 40 per cent of burglaries reported in Taranaki since the beginning of the year would have been prevented if people had locked up their property. 
Senior Sergeant Karley Hunt, of New Plymouth police, said the simple act of ensuring windows and doors were shut and secured would minimise the risk of people becoming burglary victims. 
"Burglary is a crime that makes people feel incredibly vulnerable," she said. SIMON O'CONNOR/Fairfax NZ. 
Senior Sergeant Karley Hunt is urging the public to be more security conscious following a spike in reported burglaries. 
"As well as the psychological toll of being a victim of burglary, it takes considerable time and money to replace anything stolen." 
READ MORE: * Recidivist burglar jailed after stealing TVs from homes 
Burglaries increased nationwide by 16 per cent in 2016, with 74,182 reported. Taranaki, along with the Nelson Bays, Hawkes Bay and Waikato East areas recorded the biggest jumps in overall crime reported. 
Hunt said burglaries were often committed by opportunistic offenders and the most common items stolen was property which was often in plain sight. This included bicycles, tools, clothes and plants. 
"Burglars tend to look for easy targets so the best way to reduce your chances of becoming a victim is to put obstacles in the offenders' way." she said. 
Increased measures such as the installation of alarms and cameras or deadbolts on doors were some ways people could beef up security at home. 
Residential properties were not the only premises being targeted by thieves. Ad Feedback 
Hunt said there had also been a rise in thefts from cars, burglaries from commercial premises and vehicles being stolen around the region as well. 
"Again, our intelligence suggests that some of these crimes could have been prevented if owners had taken steps to secure their property," Hunt said. 
She said if anyone noticed anything suspicious or out of place, they should contact police immediately. 
"Police can and will react to a crime being committed. However, we'd rather prevent it from happening in the first place," she said. - Stuff
